Corresponding authors. 1 Junyi Peng, and Wensheng Liao contributed equally to this work. Oxidation reaction of methane (CH4OR) into high value-added fuels using electrocatalytic pathway is attractive from the perspective of carbon emission reduction and sustainability. Nonetheless, the process involves the development of novel catalysts to facilitate CH4 activation and CC coupling succession in a stable manner. Herein, alloying activated Ni-Co bimetals (NiCo alloy/CNTs) were reported for CH4-to-C2H5OH. TEM confirmed that Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts anchored on CNTs-COOH from a microscopic point of view. The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of CH4 conversion to C2H5OH reached 75.6 % at 1.6 V vs. RHE with remained stability for 16 h. In situ ATR-SEIRAS spectroscopy and DFT analysis demonstrated that rapid generation of ethanol on the surface of the alloy catalysts, mainly CO and COH accumulation of the characteristic peaks in ethanol, following by CC coupling by *CH2OH and *CH3. The outcomes achieved here will stimulate further research into the development of alloy catalysts for the oxidation of methane to produce valuable chemicals in the field of electrocatalysis. Graphical abstract We first report that nanocrystalline Ni-Co alloy catalysts were reported for electrocatalytic oxidation of methane to ethanol. The enhanced activity and high stability of the NiCo alloy/CNTs catalysts for CH4-to-C2H5OH could be attributed to the synergistic effect with the alloy strategy. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni-Co bimetal Alloy strategy CH4 oxidation reaction C-C coupling Ethanol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane is a prevalent component of natural gas and represents a significant carbon-based energy source for the production of high value-added chemical products [1–4]. However, the elevated CH bond dissociation energy (439 kJ/mol), diminished electron affinity and feeble polarisation of methane render an exceptionally arduous undertaking without highly efficient catalysts. To achieve the desired conversion, a complex multi-electron transfer process and a multi-step proton coupling process are required [5–9]. In previous studies, noble metal catalysts have succeeded in breaking the stable tetrahedral structure of methane, such as Ag[10], Pt[11], Pt/r-TiO2[12], and Au-Rh[13]. Nevertheless, the expense and scarcity of the noble metal catalysts have thus far limited broader application. In contrast, transition metal catalysts (e.g., Ni, Co) are excellent electrocatalysts due to the cost-effectiveness and abundance of resources, for example, CoNi2OX[14], Ni/NiO[15], and ZrO2/Co3O4 catalysts [16]. Furthermore, the strong CH bond of CH4 can be effectively activated under mild conditions, leading to the selective and controllable conversion of methane into valuable chemical products [17,18]. Various strategies, including alloy[19–21], heterojunction[22], surface modification[23], and doping[24], have been employed as viable approaches for CH4OR by transition metal catalysts under mild conditions. Among the strategies, the alloy strategy attracts considerable attention due to the significant electronic effect and multifunctionality inherent to the structure [25–28]. Ding et al. [29]. reported that MoNi alloy with moderate O* activate the CH bond of CH4, thus achieving a high CH4 conversion (over 95 %) and a syngas selectivity (over 97 %) by avoiding O poisoning of the Ni site. Similarly, Sn-Ni[30] and Ni-Fe[31] alloy have been demonstrated to possess exemplary CH bonding capabilities, facilitating the activation of CH4 for the prevention of carbon accumulation in potential applications. However, the CC coupling process overcomes higher energy barriers for the generation of high-value chemicals after the CH activation procedure, thereby enhancing the robust electronic coupling of alloy and triggering the efficient electron transfer process for CH4OR [32]. Alloyed catalysts for the generation of C2+ products over CH4OR have rarely been reported. Herein, NiCo alloy/CNTs catalysts were synthesized successfully through pyrolysis of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs precursors. TEM confirmed that Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts anchored on CNTs-COOH from a microscopic point of view. The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of CH4 conversion to C2H5OH reached 75.6 % at 1.6 V vs. RHE with remained stability for 16 h. In situ ATR-SEIRAS spectroscopy and DFT analysis demonstrated that rapid generation of ethanol on the surface of the alloy catalysts, mainly CO and COH accumulation of the characteristic peaks in ethanol, following by CC coupling by *CH2OH and *CH3. Moreover, the aforementioned findings are expected to stimulate further research into the development of alloy catalysts for the oxidation of methane to produce valuable chemicals in the field of electrocatalysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis NiCo alloy/CNTs were synthesized by Ar treatment at 900 °C of Ni-Co PBA/CNT-COOH precursor. To obtain the precursor of Ni-Co PBA/CNT-COOH, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Na3C6H5O7·2H2O were dissolved in DI-water with ultrasound for 5 min denoted as solution A, K3[Co(CN)6] was recorded as solution B with the same synthesis procedure, and CNTs-COOH was added to the mixture with ultrasound for 60 min after slowly adding solution A dropwise to solution B, then aged for 24 h at room temperature and further centrifuged at 7000 rpm for 5 min. Finally, after drying at 70 °C for 24 h and purifying by DI-water and anhydrous ethanol, Ni-Co PBA/CNT-COOH precursor was obtained. Ni-Co PBA/CNT-COOH-x (x = 1, 2.5, 5, 10, 15wt %, Ni-Co PBA/CNT-COOH-5 named Ni-Co PBA/CNT-COOH) catalysts were same conditions as above for obtaining. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained with a Rigaku D/max-3C graphite monochromator and Cu-Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA, λ= 1.542 Å). The micro-morphology and elemental distribution of the samples were attained with Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, JSM-7800F), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM, FEI Talos F200S G2) with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and High-resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100F). The valence states of the elements were determined with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB250Xi) employing Al-Kα radiation (15 KV, 30 mA). The characteristic functional groups and qualitatively chemical natures of the samples were obtained using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, IRTracer-100, SHIMADZU). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical measurements of the catalysts were carried out in a standard three-electrode system using 0.1 M NaOH CH4-saturated solution (298 K) as the electrolyte in an airtight electrochemical cell with two chambers. A classical three-electrode (working, reference and counter electrode) system was employed, i.e. glassy carbon electrode (0.07 cm-2), saturated calomel electrode, and platinum foil. The electrochemical workstation was CHI-660E. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) evaluated the catalyst activity. Moreover, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was analyzed in a frequency range of 1–105 Hz, at a potential of −1.0 V vs. RHE and an amplitude of 5 mV. 2.4 In situ ATR-SEIRAS characterization In situ attenuated total reflection-surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) was measured by a three-electrode system saturated with a CH4-saturated 0.1 NaOH consisting of a Pt counter electrode, a Hg/HgCl2 reference electrode and a glassy carbon electrode as working electrode. The intermediates were detected for 1 min of constant potentials at each potential ranging from 1.4 V to 2.0 V vs. RHE. The catalyst slurry was deposited on a silicon substrate with a gold film (MSP-mini, R2–169, IXRF Systems, Inc. America). Infrared analysis equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled MCT detector (IRT racer100, Shimadzu, Japan). Electrochemical signals were generated and recorded with an electrochemical workstation (Autolab302N, Metrohm, Switzerland). 2.5 Product analysis The gaseous products were detected using a chromatograph (SC-3000B) equipped with TDX01 molecular sieve column. The liquid sample composition was analyzed using a mixture of 0.1 mL D2O and 0.05 ml dimethyl sulfoxide as an internal standard solution. The solution was subsequently mixed with 0.1 mL of electrolyte to be used for NMR detection following the electrolysis reaction. The product and current values were recorded at a constant potential for 2 h of the reaction to calculate the Faraday efficiency. 2.6 Density functional theory calculations Plane-wave density functional theory (DFT) calculation was performed on the Dmol3 package with the double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis sets. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) and DFT-D2 method were employed to electronic relations and Vander Waals interaction. A CNT-COOH with periodic boundary conditions was defined as 30 Å × 30 Å × 17 Å. The Brillouin zone integrals were obtained by calculating 1 × 1 × 1 k-point grid generated by the Monkhorst-Pack (MP) scheme. The energy tolerance accuracy, maximum force, displacement on each atom and cut-off orbital were set as 1 × 10–5 Ha, 0.002 Ha/ Å, 0.005 Å, and 3.7 Å, respectively. The cell parameters were optimized using the finite basis correction method until the stress was less than 0.05 GPa. 3 Results and discussion Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH were generated by anchoring Ni-Co PBA to CNTs-COOH after dehydrogenation of the carboxyl groups on CNTs-COOH via co-precipitation method. Subsequent pyrolysis broke the Ni-Co PBA framework structure, allowing the Ni and Co metals to form NiCo alloy anchored to CNTs as shown in Fig. 1 a. The XRD characteristic diffraction peaks pattern of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH was well indexed to the pattern of Ni-Co PBA (PDF#89–3737) and C (PDF#75–1621), indicating that Ni-Co PBA were successfully anchored to CNTs-COOH without the collapse of the framework structure [33,34]. The XRD pattern analysis of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH with different contents revealed that Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH above 5wt % were enabled to form a framework structure (Fig. S4a). However, the disappearance of the peaks on NiCo alloy/CNTs after pyrolysis of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH demonstrated that the framework structure of Ni-Co PBA collapsed, and the remaining peaks corresponded well with Ni (PDF#04–0850) and Co(PDF#15–0806), resulting in the generation of NiCo alloy/CNTs (Fig. 1 b). Furthermore, the XRD partial enlargement pattern confirmed the formation of alloys from Ni and Co metals (Fig. 1 c) [35]. The microscopic morphology of the catalysts was observed by SEM, as shown in Fig. S1a-c, all the samples retained the nanotubular properties, especially for Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH, no exposed Ni-Co PBA was found, suggesting a successful entry into the pipeline of CNTs-COOH. The TEM images further confirmed the highly dispersed granular catalysts within the nanotubes (Fig. 2 a and b). The HRTEM images revealed crystal surfaces corresponding to (440), (420), (422) for Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH and (111) for NiCo alloy/CNTs, indicating that a significant change in the metal coordination environment of NiCo alloy/CNTs (Fig. 2 c-j). Additionally, the TEM average particle size on NiCo alloy/CNTs (40.12 nm) was more than Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH (10.26 nm), illustrating the agglomeration of metals with the framework structure of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH destroyed after pyrolysis (Fig. S1d and e). Compared to Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH, elemental distribution mapping images demonstrated the formation of the alloy on NiCo alloy/CNTs in high agreement with XRD results (Fig. 2 k-n and Fig. S2). To investigate electronic structure and valence state of the elements on catalysts, XPS measure was carried out. The full XPS spectrum showed elemental information for different catalysts (Fig. 3 a and Fig. S5). As shown in Fig. S6 and 3b, the carboxyl group of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH was remained, in agreement with the peak pattern of CNTs-COOH, and decomposed to form NiCo alloy/CNTs after pyrolysis. The N 1 s edge spectra (Fig. 3 c) of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH were assigned to two peaks of pyrrolic N and pyridinic N, whereas no significant peaks were observed in the CNTs-COOH and NiCo alloy/CNTs, attributed to the cyano-group (CN) in the PBA. The Ni 2p3/2 spectra of NiCo alloy/CNTs showed three peaks at 853.09 eV, 855.47 eV, and 856.35 eV, corresponding to Ni0, Ni2+, Ni3+, respectively (Fig. 3 d) [36]. In Fig. 3 e, the peaks at binding energy of 780.7 eV and 781.63 eV were assigned to Co0 and Co3+ of Co 2p3/2, indicating that reduction of high valence NiCo metal after pyrolysis. [37–39] Combinations of monolithic metals into alloys, resulted in agreement with XRD and TEM characterization. Compared to Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH (44.3 % and 50.97 %), the decrease in high valence Ni (32.57 %) and Co (26.15 %) content of 2p3/2 on NiCo alloy/CNTs suggested the destruction of CoIII-CNNiII (Table S1). The catalyst functional groups were further characterized by FT-IR (Fig. 3 f). The cyano-groups stretching vibration unique to Ni-Co PBA/CNTs COOH were found at about 2172 cm-1. The peaks at 2925 cm-1 and 2847 cm-1 corresponded to the vibration of the alkyl chain -CH [40–42]. The C = O in the carboxyl (–COOH) group stretching frequency at 1648 cm-1 remained consistent throughout the catalysts. However, OH stretch vibration (918 cm-1) was weakened on Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH and disappeared on NiCo alloy/CNTs compared to CNTs-COOH, implying that oxygen termination after dehydrogenation anchored Ni-Co PBA to the nanotubes [43,44]. Contact angle tests showed a low hydrophilicity on Ni-Co alloy/CNTs due to the disappearance of -COOH after pyrolysis (Fig. S7) [45,46]. To establish the superior performance of NiCo alloy/CNTs, LSV, EIS, FE(ethanol) and stability tests were used to investigate the reaction kinetics of CH4 oxidation to ethanol. Compared to CNTs-COOH(1.35 V vs. RHE), Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH(1.65 V vs. RHE), and Ni-Co PBA(1.7 V vs. RHE), the onset potential of NiCo alloy/CNTs was 1.2 V vs. RHE in CH4OR. In addition, the current densities of NiCo alloy/CNTs increased significantly with the increase of the potential window (Fig. 4 a and Fig. S3–4), indicating that NiCo alloy/CNTs formed after pyrolysis were more suitable for CH4OR. In Fig. 4 b, the Nyquist plots showed smaller semicircle diameters at low frequencies on NiCo alloy/CNTs and Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH compared to Ni-Co PBA and CNTs, implying faster electron transferred from the electrode surface to the reactive molecules on CNTs loaded with Ni-Co bimetals [47]. Moreover, Fig. 4 c showed the Faraday efficiencies of the CH3CH2OH products for different catalysts at 1.2∼1.9 V vs. RHE. NiCo alloy/CNTs (75.6 % at 1.6 V vs. RHE) exhibited significant ethanol Faraday efficiency (FE), however, Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH (21.7 % at 1.6 V) and CNTs-COOH (6.2 % at 1.6 V) still retained low FEethanol. Over the NiCo alloy/CNTs electrode, the rapid activation of CH4 to *CH2OH enhanced the CC coupling with *CH3 for ethanol production. In order to test the stability of the CH4OR, as shown in Fig. 4 d, during the 16 h electrolytic process at 1.6 V vs. RHE, the current density was essentially stable as well as the partial Faraday efficiency of ethanol decreased by merely 6.1 %(from 75.4 % to 69.3 %), suggesting that the NiCo alloy/CNTs catalysts displayed excellent stability for CH4-to-CH3CH2OH. In suit ATR-SEIRAS spectra further confirmed the significant process of CH4-to-CH3CH2OH on NiCo alloy/CNTs. Fig. 5 a and b showed the spectra collected at different electrode potentials. The bands at 1316 cm-1 and 1488 cm-1 were assigned to actived-CH4(*CH4) and CH2 intermediate from subsequent hydrogenolysis, providing important evidence for probing methane cracking. CO stretching and COH stretching vibrations in ethanol were identified at 1085 cm-1 and 1050 cm-1, which were more obvious until the potential reached about 1.6 V vs. RHE on NiCo alloy /CNTs [48–51]. Times series ATR-FTIR spectra were obtained by fixing the electrode potential at 1.6 V vs. RHE to monitor the accumulation of intermediates over time (Fig. S8). As the reaction proceeded, all the peaks appeared and the peaks in ethanol accumulated to a greater extent on NiCo alloy/CNTs compared to Ni-Co PBA/CNTs-COOH. These ATR-FTIR experiments confirmed the Rapid ethanol formation of ethanol on NiCo alloy/CNTs. To clarify the role of alloy strategy on NiCo alloy/CNTs for CH4OR, DFT calculations were performed to analyze the partial density of states (PDOS). As shown in Fig. 5 c-d and Fig. S9, the d-bands of Ni and Co on Ni-Co PBA/CNTs overlapped relatively well with CN at the same energy level, attributed to the cyanide group in CoIII-CNNiII being linked to the metal, and the NiCo alloy/CNTs catalysts exhibited coupling of the Ni and Co bands confirming the alloy construction [52,53]. Moreover, changes in the electro cloud density of metal over the energy field led to changes in the coordination environment [54–57]. Compared to Ni-Co PBA/CNTs, the NiCo alloy/CNTs favoured the adsorption of CH4 and intermediate state products with more electrons in the anti-bonding state, thus contributing to the subsequent ethanol production by CC coupling. The possible reaction mechanism of CH4-to-CH3CH2OH were as follows: (1–1) * + CH4 → *CH4 (1–2) * + CH4 – e-→ *CH4+ H + (1–3) *CH3 – e-→ *CH2+H + (1–4) *CH2 – e-+ OH-→ *CH2OH (1–5) *CH2OH+ *CH3→ *CH3CH2OH (1–6) *CH3CH2OH→ * + CH3CH2OH Consequently, the active sites of Ni-Co bimetallic alloy catalysts exhibited a strong adsorption configuration for CH4. The *CH4 were converted to *CH3 and *CH2, then further oxidized to form *CH2OH. Finally, *CH2OH performed a CC coupling reaction with the previously generated *CH3 at the active sites of Ni-Co alloy to form C2H5OH(Fig. 5 e). The enhanced activity and high stability of the NiCo alloy/CNTs catalysts for CH4-to-C2H5OH could be attributed to the synergistic effect with the alloy strategy. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, NiCo alloy/CNTs catalysts were synthesized successfully through pyrolysis of Ni-Co PBA/CNTs precursors for CH4-to-C2H5OH. TEM confirmed that Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts anchored on CNTs-COOH from a microscopic point of view. The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of CH4 conversion to C2H5OH reached 75.6 % at 1.6 V vs. RHE with remained stability for 16 h. In situ ATR-SEIRAS spectroscopy and DFT analysis demonstrated that rapid generation of ethanol on the surface of the alloy catalysts, mainly CO and COH accumulation of the characteristic peaks in ethanol, following by CC coupling by *CH2OH and *CH3. Moreover, the aforementioned findings are expected to stimulate further research into the development of alloy catalysts for the oxidation of methane to produce valuable chemicals in the field of electrocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: Oxidation reaction of methane (CH4OR) into high value-added fuels using electrocatalytic pathway is attractive from the perspective of carbon emission reduction and sustainability. Nonetheless, the process involves the development of novel catalysts to facilitate CH4 activation and CC coupling succession in a stable manner. Herein, alloying activated Ni-Co bimetals (NiCo alloy/CNTs) were reported for CH4-to-C2H5OH. TEM confirmed that Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts anchored on CNTs-COOH from a microscopic point of view. The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of CH4 conversion to C2H5OH reached 75.6 % at 1.6 V vs. RHE with remained stability for 16 h. In situ ATR-SEIRAS spectroscopy and DFT analysis demonstrated that rapid generation of ethanol on the surface of the alloy catalysts, mainly CO and COH accumulation of the characteristic peaks in ethanol, following by CC coupling by *CH2OH and *CH3. The outcomes achieved here will stimulate further research into the development of alloy catalysts for the oxidation of methane to produce valuable chemicals in the field of electrocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Ni-Co bimetal catalysts anchored on MWCNTS-COOH for enhancing CH4 electrooxidation to C2H5OH
